sections.title: Introduction to Redis
sections.description: Learn the fundamentals of Redis, an in-memory data store used for caching, real-time analytics, and message brokering. This section covers what Redis is and how to set it up locally.

lessons.title: What is Redis and Why Use It
lessons.content: Redis is an in-memory data store that can be used as a cache, message broker, and key-value database. It is extremely fast due to storing data in memory and supports various data structures like strings, hashes, lists, sets, and sorted sets.

examples.description: Using Redis to store a user session that expires after 1 hour.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical use case of Redis?
quiz.hint: Redis is key-value based, not relational.
quiz.explanation: Redis is not used for relational database operations like joins; it is primarily for caching, messaging, and fast key-value storage.

lessons.challenge: Explain three scenarios where Redis can improve performance in a web application.
tips: Redis stores data in memory for extremely fast access.
It supports TTL to automatically expire keys.

lessons.title: Installing and Running Redis
lessons.content: Redis can be installed locally on Windows, macOS, or Linux. The Redis CLI allows you to interact with the database, run commands, and check the server status.

examples.code:
# macOS (Homebrew)
brew install redis
brew services start redis

# Test Redis CLI
redis-cli ping
examples.description: Installing Redis via Homebrew on macOS and checking server status with PING command.

quiz.question: Which command checks if the Redis server is running?
quiz.explanation: Sending PING to Redis returns PONG if the server is running.

lessons.challenge: Install Redis locally and verify it is running using redis-cli.
tips: Use Redis Desktop Manager or another GUI for easier exploration.
Always check Redis version after installation to ensure compatibility.

sections.title: Redis Basics
sections.description: Understand core Redis data types and basic commands for storing, retrieving, and manipulating data.

lessons.title: Redis Data Types
lessons.content: Redis supports multiple data types: Strings, Lists, Sets, Hashes, and Sorted Sets. Each type has specialized commands and use cases, like queues, rankings, or structured objects.

examples.code:
SET mykey "Hello Redis"
LPUSH mylist "Task1"
SADD myset "user1"
HSET user:1001 name "Alice" age 25
ZADD leaderboard 100 "player1"
examples.description: Examples showing Redis commands for different data types.

quiz.question: Which Redis data type is best suited for storing unique elements?
quiz.explanation: Sets in Redis only store unique values, making them ideal for lists of distinct items.

lessons.challenge: Create a Redis Hash for a product with fields: name, price, stock.
tips: Use Lists for queues or ordered data.
Use Sorted Sets for leaderboards with scores.

lessons.title: Basic Redis Commands
lessons.content: Learn essential Redis commands like SET, GET, DEL, EXISTS, INCR, and EXPIRE to manage data and implement TTL.

examples.code:
SET counter 0
INCR counter
GET counter
EXPIRE counter 60
DEL counter
EXISTS counter
examples.description: Using commands to manipulate keys and values, increment counters, set expiration, and check existence.

quiz.question: Which command increments a numeric value in Redis?
quiz.hint: It only works on numeric strings.
quiz.explanation: INCR increases the integer value of a key by 1.

lessons.challenge: Create a key 'visits', increment it on each API call, and set it to expire after 10 minutes.
tips: Use EXPIRE to automatically remove old cache entries.
Check key existence with EXISTS before operating.

sections.title: Advanced Data Structures
sections.description: Learn how to work with complex Redis data structures and implement time-based caching with TTL.

lessons.title: Working with Lists, Sets, and Hashes
lessons.content: Lists support push/pop operations, Sets support unique element management, and Hashes store structured objects in key-value pairs.

examples.code:
LPUSH tasks "Task1" "Task2"
RPUSH tasks "Task3"
LPOP tasks
SADD users "user1" "user2"
HSET session:1001 token "abc123" user "Alice"
examples.description: Examples demonstrating operations on lists, sets, and hashes.

quiz.question: Which command removes the first element of a Redis list?
quiz.explanation: LPOP removes and returns the first element of a list.

lessons.challenge: Implement a task queue using LPUSH and RPOP in Redis.
tips: Lists are ideal for queues (FIFO) or stacks (LIFO).
Use Hashes to store multiple fields for a single entity efficiently.

lessons.title: Using Sorted Sets and TTL
lessons.content: Sorted Sets allow ranking items with scores, and TTL lets keys expire automatically after a set time.

examples.code:
ZADD leaderboard 50 "player1"
ZADD leaderboard 100 "player2"
ZRANGE leaderboard 0 -1 WITHSCORES
SET temp_key "data" EX 60
examples.description: Using Sorted Sets for rankings and EXPIRE (TTL) for auto-deleting keys.

quiz.question: Which Redis data type maintains order based on scores?
quiz.hint: Used for leaderboards and ranking systems.
quiz.explanation: Sorted Sets store members with scores and always keep them sorted by score.

lessons.challenge: Create a leaderboard for top 5 scores and remove entries after 1 hour using TTL.
tips: Use TTL for session storage or temporary data.
Sorted Sets are perfect for ranking and scoring systems.

sections.title: Redis with Node.js
sections.description: Integrate Redis with Node.js to improve performance, implement caching, and manage data efficiently.

lessons.title: Connecting Redis with Node.js
lessons.content: Install the 'redis' package and connect using async/await. Redis clients allow storing and retrieving data from Node.js applications.

examples.description: Connecting a Node.js application to Redis and handling connection events.

quiz.question: Which npm package is commonly used for Redis in Node.js?
quiz.explanation: The 'redis' package is widely used to connect Node.js applications to Redis.

lessons.challenge: Set up a Node.js app that connects to Redis and logs a success message on connection.
tips: Use async/await for Redis commands in modern Node.js apps.
Always handle error events to prevent crashes.

lessons.title: Storing and Retrieving Data
lessons.content: Use Redis commands in Node.js to SET, GET, and manage key-value data asynchronously.

examples.description: Storing and retrieving a simple key-value pair in Redis using Node.js.

quiz.question: Which Redis command retrieves the value of a key?
quiz.explanation: GET returns the value stored for a specified key.

lessons.challenge: Store user session data in Redis and retrieve it on request.
tips: Always check if keys exist before retrieving.
Use JSON.stringify/parse for storing objects.

lessons.title: Implementing Caching
lessons.content: Cache frequently requested data in Redis to reduce database load and improve API response times.

examples.description: Middleware that serves cached responses from Redis if available.

quiz.question: Why use Redis for caching in Node.js?
quiz.hint: Caching avoids repeated heavy computations or DB queries.
quiz.explanation: Redis caching stores frequently accessed data in memory for fast retrieval.

lessons.challenge: Implement caching for an Express API endpoint using Redis.
tips: Always set expiration for cached data to avoid stale responses.
Use Redis for read-heavy workloads to improve performance.

sections.title: Redis Use Cases
sections.description: Explore practical use cases of Redis in web applications including session management, authentication, rate-limiting, and background jobs.

lessons.title: Session Storage and Authentication
lessons.content: Redis is commonly used to store user sessions for Express apps, making authentication scalable and fast.

examples.description: Storing Express session data in Redis to persist user login state.

quiz.question: Why use Redis for session storage?
quiz.hint: Sessions should be quick and scalable.
quiz.explanation: Redis stores sessions in memory, enabling quick access and handling many concurrent users.

lessons.challenge: Configure an Express app to store session data in Redis for logged-in users.
tips: Always set secure options for production sessions.
Use TTL to expire sessions automatically.

lessons.title: Rate Limiting and Queues
lessons.content: Use Redis to implement API rate limiting, throttling, and background job queues with lists or sorted sets.

examples.description: Throttling API requests to 10 per minute per user using Redis.

quiz.question: Which Redis feature helps implement rate-limiting?
quiz.hint: Increment counter for each request and expire it.
quiz.explanation: INCR combined with TTL allows tracking request counts over time for rate-limiting.

lessons.challenge: Implement a simple job queue using Redis lists for background tasks.
tips: Use sorted sets for priority queues.
Always monitor queue length to avoid memory issues.

sections.title: Redis Administration & Best Practices
sections.description: Learn about persistence, backup, security, and monitoring for production-ready Redis deployments.

lessons.title: Persistence, Backup, and Security
lessons.content: Redis provides RDB snapshots and AOF persistence options. Use strong passwords, firewalls, and monitoring tools to secure and manage Redis in production.

examples.code:
# Enable RDB snapshots in redis.conf
save 900 1
save 300 10
save 60 10000

# Set password
requirepass yourpassword
examples.description: Example Redis configuration for snapshot persistence and password protection.

quiz.question: Which Redis feature persists data to disk?
quiz.explanation: RDB snapshots and AOF logs allow Redis data to survive restarts.

lessons.challenge: Configure Redis to require a password and take periodic snapshots of the database.
tips: Use monitoring tools like RedisInsight or Prometheus.
Regularly backup Redis data to prevent accidental loss.
